Temporary shutdown of public buildings  All activities within the state, municipalities and regions that are not necessary should remain closed until 7 February 2021. This applies, for example, to bathhouses, sports halls and museums.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125005255/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change: the temporary shutdown of public buildings continues, so that all activities within the state, municipalities and regions that are not necessary should remain closed until 7 February 2021. This applies, for example, to bathhouses, sports halls and museums.    Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person is given ten square meters of space. The companies must display clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.       There are extensive hygiene measures in place for restaurants, cafés and pubs. The serving of alcoholic beverages and alcoholic beverage-like preparations is prohibited between 20.00 and 11.00 until 7 February 2021.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210204143008/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Public buildings have reopened on 8th February. Most workplaces can open with special measures in place, but a number of workplaces are forced to close in relation to the ban on public gatherings of over 8 people, such as fairground amusements and parades, and markets and fairs.     Restaurants, cafés and pubs can open, but the size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to four people. If a party is larger than eight people, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them. The serving of alcoholic beverages is prohibited between 20.00 and 11.00.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210212174105/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change, but the government is preparing new measures as listed in the M1 note for 17 Feb. Until further notice, no more than eight people may be present at a public gathering or public event. The police has the right to cancel or dissolve an event that has more than eight attendees.   If a private gathering is held at an event venue, in a meeting room and at other rented premises, a maximum of eight people are allowed to attend.    Hence coding is 2G per interpretation guidelines when C4=4    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125005255/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change: public gatherings and events may have a maximum of eight participants. The police can cancel or disband a public gathering or event with more participants. Anyone who organises an event that violates the ban can face a fine or prison sentence of a maximum of six months.   At funerals, 20 participants are allowed.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210204143008/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

For travel in Sweden, you should avoid crowds, rush hour traffic, public transport without booking a place, and avoid meeting new people other than those you normally hang out with. You should also be able to isolate yourself at your destination and get home in a way that does not increase the risk of infecting others if you should get symptoms of Covid-19. Temporary entry ban to Sweden  The Swedish Government has decided to stop non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban will be in effect until March 31. This ban has been introduced to mitigate the effects of the coronavirus outbreak, and to reduce the spread of Covid-19.   The entry ban does not apply to citizens and their families from EU/EEA countries and Switzerland. Moreover, the ban does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210125010813/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

The test result must not be older than 48 hours. The new rules supplement the previous entry ban. There will be relaxations and exemptions, including for cross-border workers.

The Swedish Government has decided to stop non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban will be in effect until March 31. This ban has been introduced to mitigate the effects of the coronavirus outbreak, and to reduce the spread of Covid-19.   The entry ban does not apply to citizens and their families from EU/EEA countries and Switzerland. Moreover, the ban does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.  A temporary ban on entry to Sweden for nationals from the UK, Denmark and Norway is in effect.    Exceptions may be made, such as for:  •    Anyone working or living in Sweden can enter from Denmark.  •    Children going to meet parents living in Sweden and their escort.  •    Those travelling in health service vehicles.    In addition to the entry ban, foreign nationals need to present a negative Covid-19 test result no older than 48h in order to travel into Sweden.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210212193443/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

No change: non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU is banned until March 31; temporary ban on entry to Sweden for nationals from the UK, Denmark and Norway (with exceptions); all foreign nationals need to present a negative Covid-19 test result no older than 48h in order to travel into Sweden.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210219205333/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

Short-term lay-offs may currently be granted for a maximum of nine consecutive months. The Government will propose that this time limit be temporarily removed until 30 June 2021. In practice, this means that short-term lay-offs granted in 2020 can be extended by up to a further seven months, or until 30 June 2021 at the latest.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125013744/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/11/additional-crisis-measures-for-businesses/

The Public Health Agency of Sweden recommends that adults with symptoms of COVID-19 get tested to see if they have an ongoing infection. The same recommendation applies to children of school age and older, i.e., from about 6 years of age. Younger children of preschool age are primarily advised to stay at home if they are ill, without taking a test. It is the regions that decide which people to test, and there may be regional variations from the national recommendations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125020028/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/

Diplomat argues that Tajikistan’s government has not proven itself to be an accurate source of information on the pandemic. The government perpetually reproduces the narrative that it is strong, able to face any challenge, and the pandemic has been no different. An RFE/RL investigation last summer concluded that Tajikistan’s official coronavirus statistics didn’t match reality and reporting on the reality has become increasingly difficult. Tajik authorities blocked a critical news website, Akhbor, in April 2020. Also, Tajik authorities changed the country’s Criminal Code to punish reporting “disinformation” on the virus. Moreover, on January 26 Tajikistan President announced that the country does not have COVID-19 cases and the country completely defeated the COVID-19. The President urged citizens to follow hygiene rules.   Links: https://archive.vn/GuRLt https://archive.vn/L94MD https://archive.vn/An4AE
No changes found

No testing policy has been reported. The previous publications of Diplomat suggested that Tajikistan has a lack of capacity to actually test for the virus in hospitals and the government pressures on staff to avoid diagnosing it. Thus the prevailing belief among analysts that Tajikistan’s official numbers are, at best, vast undercounts and at worst absolute fabrications.  Link: https://archive.vn/GuRLt

The government continues to close its border. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "All international commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan have been cancelled and land borders are closed to passenger traffic. Some press reporting indicates that international flight restrictions are expected to continue through January 1, 2020."    "Commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan are suspended. Occasional, tightly controlled, charter flights are the only means of entering or leaving the country by air."    "As part of ongoing efforts to limit the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19), authorities in Turkmenistan have extended their suspensions of international flights until at least Jan. 31. Domestic rail and bus services also remain suspended until at least Jan. 31. All land borders with Afghanistan, Iran, Kazakhstan, and Uzbekistan remain closed until further notice. Only Turkmen nationals, permanent residents, diplomats, and workers in critical industries and key infrastructure are permitted to enter the country. All arrivals must undergo a 14-day quarantine in a state-run facility. While freight traffic is generally allowed to transit the border, Turkmen authorities have previously restricted cross-border freight traffic without warning or explanation. All persons departing the country must be in possession of a negative COVID-19 test certificate, signed within the previous 24 hours."    https://archive.fo/cxSs5    https://archive.vn/bUERh#selection-1611.0-1611.348    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20210128074335/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

All international commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan have been canceled and?land borders?are?closed?to passenger traffic. Charter flights are organized by Foreign Missions and private companies. Some press reporting indicates that international?flight restrictions are expected to continue.  Link: https://archive.vn/CQuNg
The government continues to not offer any income support. No relevant information can be found in articles reviewing the country’s economic policy.    https://archive.vn/pdIkh

From 1 January 2021, the government increased the amount of salary, scholarships, pensions. However, the government has not announced any income support policy. On 27 January, it was reported that a third of employees of one of the Turkmenabat Silk Production Association manufacturies were dismissed. There are no income support measures were reported.   Links: https://archive.vn/BHXeR https://archive.vn/ZfXCP

The authorities provided temporary suspension of loan repayments to businesses affected by the COVID containment measures.    See IMF website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210203100406/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#T

There is no debt/contract relief policy in Turkmenistan. According to the Rodio Ozodi report, due to COVID-19, it has become very difficult for people to timely pay for gas, electricity, and water.  Links: https://archive.vn/IrZLj https://archive.vn/wFZzk

The government continues to deny the existence of any COVID case in the country, but there are coordinated public information campaigns in place.     "The Government of Turkmenistan’s Ministry of Health has established a COVID-19 hotline (tel. +993 12 73 9535) where citizens may receive information about the virus, including prevention and treatment, in both Russian and Turkmen languages."    https://archive.fo/cxSs5

The Government of Turkmenistan’s Ministry of Health has established a COVID-19 hotline (tel. +993 12 73 9535) where citizens may receive information about the virus, including prevention and treatment, in both Russian and Turkmen languages.  Link: https://archive.vn/CQuNg

The government continues to not implement any testing policy since it continues to deny the presence of COVID in the country.     However, according to the US Embassy in Turkmenistan, "COVID-19 testing is offered in Ashgabat at Jemgyyetcilik Saglygy we Iymit Merkezi (the Virology Laboratory of the Public Health and Nutrition Center) on Gorgoly 84, Ashgabat. The test costs 100 manat for citizens of Turkmenistan and $43 for foreign citizens." Whether citizens of Turkmenistan can actually access the COVID test is unclear.    https://archive.fo/cxSs5

COVID-19 testing is offered in Ashgabat at Jemgyyetcilik Saglygy we Iymit Merkezi (the Virology Laboratory of the Public Health and Nutrition Center) on Gorgoly 84, Ashgabat. The test costs 100 manats for citizens of Turkmenistan and $43 for foreign citizens.  Link: https://archive.vn/CQuNg

The government continues to not implement any contact tracing measures. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still denies the presence of COVID in the country.    https://archive.vn/bUERh#selection-1607.0-1607.900

The government is not conducting testing for the general public. The test costs 100 manats for citizens of Turkmenistan and $43 for foreign citizens. There is no information on contact tracing.   Link: https://archive.vn/CQuNg

The government continues to require people to wear masks in public spaces. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "Masks are required in most public places, including public transit."    "It is compulsory to wear a facemask when in public."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208052008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://archive.fo/cxSs5    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20210128074335/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

It is compulsory to wear a facemask when in public. Individuals who do not wear face coverings in public, including while driving in an automobile, may be subject to fines.  Links: https://archive.vn/2U14B https://archive.vn/CQuNg
Some organizations require staff to sign a receipt for wearing a face mask.  Link: https://archive.vn/n5QTt

According to the Russian Direct Investment Fund (RDIF), the Turkmenistan government has registered Russia's Sputnik-V vaccine." The vaccine received emergency use authorisation without the need for additional trials to be conducted in Turkmenistan." However, it is unclear whether people have already started to be vaccinated.     https://archive.vn/Evnt8    https://archive.vn/wT1kV

Mass vaccination of Russia's Sputnik V is planned to begin on 15 February in Turkmenistan. In the first stage, elderly people, teachers, citizens with chronic diseases, and medical workers will be vaccinated.  Link: https://archive.vn/HBlur

As of 14 February, protests against a controversial administrative appointment at Bogazici University continue. Passengers failing to submit a digital or paper copy of a negative PCR test result are not permitted to board the flights. Those who are in transit, are not required to submit a PCR test in Turkey. Passengers departing from the United Kingdom will not be allowed to enter Turkey. All passengers arriving in Turkey through third countries, who visited The United Kingdom within the last 10 days, will be quarantined for 14 days at places selected by the Turkish officials following their arrival. Passengers arriving from Denmark and South Africa should declare their residency address and stay in isolation for 7 days.   Link: https://archive.fo/2qeZb

Only Turkish citizens, holders of Turkish residency cards and blue card holders are permitted to board flights departing from Denmark and South Africa and arriving in Turkey.     Passengers failing to submit a digital or paper copy of a negative PCR test result are not permitted to board the flights.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210131014418/https://tr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

All international passengers age 6 years and older traveling to Turkey are required to have taken a COVID-19 PCR test with a negative result within 72 hours prior to their flight. Passengers failing to submit a digital or paper copy of a negative PCR test result are not permitted to board the flight to Turkey. Passengers departing from the United Kingdom will not be allowed to enter Turkey. All passengers arriving in Turkey through third countries, who visited The United Kingdom within the last 10 days, will be quarantined for 14 days at places selected by the Turkish officials following their arrival. Passengers arriving from Denmark and South Africa should declare their residency address and stay in isolation for 7 days. PCR testing is available at Istanbul Airport. Those who are in transit, are not required to submit a PCR test in Turkey.  Link: https://archive.fo/wUcPH

Those who are in transit, are not required to submit a PCR test in Turkey. Passengers departing from the United Kingdom will not be allowed to enter Turkey. As of 14 February, arrivals from Brazil, the United Kingdom, Denmark, and South Africa are suspended.    All passengers arriving in Turkey from other countries who visited Brazil, United Kingdom, Denmark, and South Africa (including in transit) within the last 10 days will be quarantined for 14 days at places selected by local Turkish authorities on arrival. On the 10th day of the quarantine period, passengers are required to undergo a PCR test and if the test result is negative, the isolation period will end.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214212732/https://tr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

On 4 February, the decision to postpone the loan debts of tradesmen and craftsmen to Halkbank was published in the Official Gazette.    The measure is effective from 1 January 2021 until 30 June 2021.    Coded as 0 because the measure is not targeted at households.     During the postponement period, the portion of the installment / principal debt and the interest to be accrued on the tradesmen and craftsmen in accordance with the relevant decisions, and the bank and insurance transactions tax related to this amount will be added equally to the remaining installments.    Within the scope of the decision, a letter of undertaking will be taken from the tradesmen and craftsmen whose loans are postponed , stating that they will not reduce the number of employees during the postponement period. Tradesmen and craftsmen with a decrease in the number of employees will be excluded from the scope of postponement.    Tradesmen and craftsmen, whose debts are deferred, may be granted a low-interest loan by the Bank within the scope of the relevant decisions regarding the provision of low-interest loans upon their request, and the provisions preventing the opening of loans to those who have debts subject to deferral will not be applied in such decisions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214091401/https://www.resmigazete.gov.tr/eskiler/2021/02/20210204-10.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210216005501/https://www.aa.com.tr/tr/ekonomi/esnaf-ve-sanatkarlarin-kredi-borclarina-erteleme/2133337

Turkey began administering the shots developed by China’s Sinovac to health workers (Group A) on Thursday, 14th of January rolling out a nationwide vaccination program.  Links: https://archive.fo/wip/Pl16u and https://archive.fo/wip/thTBc
More than 800 000 health staff (Group A) have been vaccinated in Turkey with Chinese Sinovac vaccine from CoronoVac firm.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/YSZm0
More than 800 000 health staff have been vaccinated in Turkey with Chinese Sinovac vaccine from CoronoVac firm.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/YSZm0 and https://archive.fo/wip/qA4lj

A,C:    On 28 January, vaccination efforts were expanded to people at the age of 75 and above.    People are receiving CoronaVac, developed by China’s Sinovac, an inactive vaccine the country started receiving shipments of last month.    Health care workers were the first to receive the shots, and under a mass vaccination plan, the elderly citizens are next in line. The age limit will gradually drop in line with the plan.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210201020353/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/coronavirus-vaccination-in-turkey-begins-for-citizens-75-and-above/news

On 28th of January, the vaccination of the citizens at the age of 75 and above was started with Chinese Sinovac vaccine from CoronoVac firm.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210201020353/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/coronavirus-vaccination-in-turkey-begins-for-citizens-75-and-above/news

On 28th of January, the vaccination of the citizens at the age of 75 and above was started with Chinese Sinovac vaccine from CoronoVac firm.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210201020353/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/coronavirus-vaccination-in-turkey-begins-for-citizens-75-and-above/news

A,C:     On 11 February, health care workers, who were first to receive jabs last month, started receiving the second dose of CoronaVac. The inactive vaccine developed by China’s Sinovac is the only one available in the country, which plans to receive its first doses of the messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine developed by Pfizer-BioNTech later this month.    While health care workers received their second jabs, people at the age of 70 and above are being administered their first shots.     The country's oldest citizens were vaccinated with their first jabs shortly after the first doses were administered to health care workers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214044314/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/2nd-shot-at-hope-turkey-starts-new-round-of-covid-19-vaccines/news

A,C:    On 12 February, people at the age of 65 or above will receive their first shots.    After completing the vaccination of senior citizens, the country will move to age-independent vaccination in the next phase of the plan. These people include soldiers, police officers, teachers and people working in sectors critical for daily life, from logistics to the food sector.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214044314/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/2nd-shot-at-hope-turkey-starts-new-round-of-covid-19-vaccines/news

A,C:    During 13-14 February, inoculation is planned for members of the Cabinet, in a bid to set an example for the public. Vaccine skeptics and anti-vaxxers thrive on social media, looking to deter inoculation, though surveys show a large majority of people are willing to be vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214044314/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/2nd-shot-at-hope-turkey-starts-new-round-of-covid-19-vaccines/news

At midnight on January 25, the intensified quarantine restrictions, which lasted from January 8, ceased to apply in Ukraine. From now and till February 28 inclusive, the country returned to the anti-epidemic rules in force in December 2020. Returning to adaptive quarantine may be considered based on the epidemiological situation.   What is prohibited:   - Visiting educational institutions by groups of more than 20 people, except for preschool, general secondary, out-of-school and specialized art education institutions.   - Visiting educational institutions when more than 50% of students and staff of the educational institution are in self-isolation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210201235758/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni  (link corrected on 16 February 2021)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125213141/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/operativna-informacija-pro-poshirennja-koronavirusnoi-infekcii-2019-cov19

Current quarantine measures are in place till February 28.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207003902/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210201235758/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni

At midnight on January 25, the intensified quarantine restrictions, which lasted from January 8, ceased to apply in Ukraine. From now and till February 28 inclusive, the country returned to the anti-epidemic rules in force in December 2020. Returning to adaptive quarantine may be considered based on the epidemiological situation.  What is prohibited:   - The work of business entities in which employees are not provided with masks, no marking on the distance between customers of 1.5 m, and visitors do not have properly worn personal protective equipment.   - The work of catering establishments from 23:00 to 7:00 (except for delivery and takeaway orders). Settlement operations are terminated after 22:00.   - Activities of accommodation establishments (except for hotels, rehabilitation centers for people with disabilities, sanatoriums).   - The work of gyms and fitness centers, if they have more than one person per 20 square meters.   - Carrying out of discos, work of night clubs and public catering establishments with the organization of leisure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210201235758/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni  (link corrected on 16 February 2021)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125213141/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/operativna-informacija-pro-poshirennja-koronavirusnoi-infekcii-2019-cov19

At midnight on January 25, the intensified quarantine restrictions, which lasted from January 8, ceased to apply in Ukraine. From now and till February 28 inclusive, the country returned to the anti-epidemic rules in force in December 2020. Returning to adaptive quarantine may be considered based on the epidemiological situation.   What is prohibited:   - Carrying out mass events (performances, holidays, concerts) in educational institutions with the participation of children from more than one group / class and in the presence of visitors.   - Carrying out mass cultural (including concerts), sports, social, advertising and other events in which more than 20 people take part and the distance of 1.5 m between the participants is not observed (exception - official and professional sports events without spectators, notary exams and events necessary to ensure the work of the authorities).   - Carrying out in entertaining establishments and public catering establishments of celebratory actions, banquets, master classes, public events.   - Operation of cinemas and cultural institutions with more than 50% of seats in one hall. - Reception of visitors in museums, exhibitions, galleries, there is more than one person per 10 square meters.   - Religious events: indoors - subject to the presence of more than one person per 5 square meters. m; in the open air - provided that the distance of 1.5 m between those present is not observed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210201235758/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni  (link corrected on 16 February 2021)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125213141/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/operativna-informacija-pro-poshirennja-koronavirusnoi-infekcii-2019-cov19

On 02 February, the Ministry of Finance presented a detailed analysis of the use of the COVID Response Fund in 2020 by the main budget institutions. In 2020, the amount of funds allocated from the COVID-19 Response Fund made up UAH 78.4 billion out of UAH 80.9 billion. In particular, from the general fund there was used UAH 63.7 billion out of the allocated UAH 72 billion, the special fund - UAH 2.8 billion out of the allocated UAH 6.4 billion.  The Ministry of Economic Development, Trade and Agriculture used UAH 8.8 billion out of UAH 10.7 billion, or 82.1%.  The funds were used to pay unemployment benefits, for one-time compensation to business entities for the payment of a single contribution as the obligatory state social insurance, for the payment of one-time pecuniary aid to business entities.    The Ministry of Social Policy used UAH 4 billion out of UAH 6.8 billion or 59.8% under the general fund and UAH 2.8 billion out of UAH 5.0 billion or 55.5% under the special fund.  The funds are used to provide insurance benefits for temporary incapacity, to make payments to family members of physicians who died due to COVID-19, to provide assistance to children of self-employed persons, to provide one-time financial assistance to insured persons in case of loss of income if their area of activity was completely prohibited during the quarantine restrictions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207004150/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/minfin-predstavlyaye-detalnij-analiz-vikoristannya-koshtiv-fondu-borotbi-z-covid-u-2020-roci-golovnimi-rozporyadnikami

On 26 January, the Prime Minister reminded that the National Vaccination Plan envisages 5 stages, in particular, vaccination of medical workers, the military, people in nursing homes, social workers, teachers, etc. The overall goal of the plan, according to Denys Shmyhal, is to cover at least 50% of the population by the end of 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207004635/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/premyer-ministr-ukrayina-bude-zabezpechena-neobhidnoyu-kilkistyu-efektivnih-vakcin

On 03 February, the Prime Minister announced the process of immunization of Ukrainians with the COVID-19 vaccine will begin in February and in the coming weeks, Ukraine will receive Pfizer/BioNTech vaccines.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210207004346/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/premyer-ministr-rozpoviv-podrobici-procesu-vakcinaciyi-v-ukrayini

On 05 February, the Ministry of Health received confirmation of the supply of 12 million doses of vaccines for the prevention of Covid-19 manufactured by AstraZeneca and NovaVax. Delivery will take place starting from February 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207005456/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-otrimae-sche-12-mln-doz-vakcin-vid-covid-19

The Ministry of Health plans to start a COVID-19 vaccination campaign in February 2021. The ban on flights from Great Britain, Italy, Germany, Denmark, Austria, Australia, the Netherlands, and South Africa is effective until February 1. It should be noted that the government of Uzbekistan suspended flights with the abovementioned countries on 21 December 2020. However, Uzbekistan has recently resumed the flights to Dushanbe, Delhi, and Kazan. On 21 January, the law "On employment of the population" came into force. Accordingly, citizens who lost their jobs in the past 12 months are paid unemployment benefits in the amount of 50 percent of the average monthly wage.   Links: https://archive.vn/AOl4u https://archive.vn/0rGtQ

Support measures. The government reacted quickly and in proportion to the shock experienced by the economy. An Anti-Crisis Fund of UZS 10 trn sum (EUR 950 m or 1.5% of GDP) was created to cover immediate social needs and to support businesses and employment. Since February, a total of about 2.5% of GDP has been spent, accounting for a cumulative increase in social payments of 17% and of minimum wages by 10% (OECD, 2020[19]).    OECD Web Archived Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210206004922/http://www.oecd.org/coronavirus/policy-responses/covid-19-crisis-response-in-central-asia-5305f172/
No changes found

Currently, there is no debt relief policy for a private household. However, the government intends to extend some exemptions and benefits for about 20 thousand businesses in the field of transport, tourism, and catering until the end of 2021.   Link: https://archive.vn/iURBY https://archive.vn/DWk6z https://archive.vn/CTF5S

During the summer, additional support measures were developed, mainly extending measures developed under the initial package and expanding unconditional income support measures for households. According to official data to July, UZS 2.3 trn of tax incentives were provided to economic sectors, and by the end of August, USD 6.1 bn had been spent, mostly to support businesses and household incomes through the Anti-Crisis Fund. The Government of Uzbekistan has established an official Telegram channel for information on COVID-19 related measures. The channel can be found at https://t.me/koronavirusinfouz. Also, the government has launched the hotline - 1003 - for medical questions related to COVID-19, with the information provided in Russian and Uzbek only.   Link: https://archive.vn/5bc9e

According to data collected by the Ministry of Public Education, from October to December, a total of 270 information sessions were conducted based on the UNFPA-developed teachers’ manual on healthy lifestyle, sexual and reproductive health, and COVID-19 prevention in Samarkand region, Tashkent Region and Karakalpakstan. The sessions reached a total of  8365 persons.  • UNICEF, the MoH and the National Agency for Electronic Mass Media (NAEMM) produced and broadcast a talk-show on mental health during COVID-19. The programme focused on pre-school children, adolescents and parents.  • UNICEF, the MoH and NAEMM produced and broadcast a TV programme on pre-school reopening during COVID-19. The programme highlighted the importance ensuring a safe school environment, provided information on measures taken to reduce infection and spread of COVID-19 at school facilities, and highlighted the importance of hygiene and physical distancing. Individuals who are showing COVID-19 symptoms will undergo testing at government facilities.  Link: https://archive.vn/hMl5w

Efforts to improve testing capacity, isolation measures, treatment and contact tracing were being scaled up as part of a solid, whole-of-government approach. The country had set up designated COVID-19 triage and treatment centres, and organized hospital structures and administrative systems for patient care.    Web archived link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210209165839/https://www.euro.who.int/en/countries/uzbekistan/news/news/2020/9/uzbekistans-covid-19-response-focuses-on-core-public-health-measures-and-community-resilience

Those who have been in contact with a person who tests positive for COVID-19 will no longer be automatically quarantined but required to self-isolate for 14-days and subject to medical monitoring. For example, on 22 January, a student from the Tashkent state pedagogical university was tested positive for COVID-19, and contact people were recommended to self-isolate for 14 days.
